Yesterday I finally go around to installing my old Rex6000 onto my wife's XP machine.  In the past this has been a nightmare because XP is not officially supported especially for the USB docking station.  Anyway, I went to Intel's website and learned how completely they had dropped the REX and any support for it.  Fortunately, they had a reference to the http://www.rex6000.org web site which had tons of info.... more than when managed by Xircom even.

The step-by-step procedure of installing the REX6000 and USB cradle was as follows:

  1. Download Intellisync 1.01 software.
  2. Decompress the Intellisync 1.01 software.
  3. Shut down all other software.  This is done because the install is likely to cause a crash of you system.
  4. Plug in USB Cradle
  5. When prompted for hardware drivers choose to provide your own and browse to the W2K folder on the of the Intellisync 1.01 software.
  6. Multiple devices will be recognized and for each you follow the same procedure of browsing for the drivers in the W2K folder.
  7. If <<KABOOM>>>>

      8. After the system restarts, "open up the registry editor [Start->Run = regedit], and go to HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Memory Management.  Now add a REG_DWORD value name "EnforceWriteProtection" (sans quotes, of course), and set that to 0 (which is the default for a newly created value anyway); it this value is already present, just change the (most likely value of) 1 to 0 ... reboot, and you should be able to install fine (with or without Windows2000 compatibility mode)"

      (I never knew about this registry setting before.... kinda cool!  It allows applications to overwrite kernel memory.)

  8. Continue the installation by browsing for the drivers based on the dialogs shown by the New Hardware Wizard.
  9. Run the install from the Intellisync 1.01 software.

After getting everything installed the next problem I had was synchronizing with Outlook 2002.  For some reason I could not synchronize contacts in a public folder even though they were part of my public folder favorites.  According to notes Office XP issues this relates to the folders being offline.  However, this did not seem to be the case for me because my "default" contacts folder worked fine.  To solve this I used the Outlook PCS software to synchronize all contacts to the local contacts folder and synchronize with that.

One last note:  The REX6000 website also had a bunch of REX Add-ins and a rudimentary REX SDK.  I don't believe Xircom made any of this stuff available so it is really cool that others have done the work.  The website give the impression these things are almost becoming collectors items....  Personally I have moved on to Pocket PC devices but the REX 6000 is serving my wife now and I am pleased that is is still fully functional (after some workarounds) with Windows XP.
